Study: Climatic influences on the worldwide spread of SARS-CoV-2 (medrxiv)
Effect: asynchronous seasonal global outbreaks are expected
Measure of Evidence: Data from WHO on infected patients worldwide

Study: Susceptible supply limits the role of climate in the COVID-19 pandemic (medrxiv)
Effect: summer temperatures will not substantially limit pandemic growth.

Study: Eco-epidemiological assessment of the COVID-19 epidemic in China, January-February 2020 (medrxiv)
Factors Described: Population Density, Temperature, Solar Radiation and Precipitation
Effect: brighter, warmer and drier conditions were associated with lower incidence

Study: Climate effect on COVID-19 spread rate: an online surveillance tool (medrxiv)
Effect: negative correlation between warmer climate and COVID-19 spread

Study: Causal empirical estimates suggest COVID-19 transmission rates are highly seasonal (medrxiv)
Effect: 1C increase in local temperature reduces new COVID-19 cases per 1 million people by 13%, with a 95% confidence interval of [-21%, -4%]
Decreased virus growth rate with increased temperature

Study: Climate affects global patterns of COVID-19 early outbreak dynamics (medrxiv)
Effect: Temperature and humidity strongly impact the variation of the growth rate of Covid-19 cases across the globe.

Study: Modeling the Corona Virus Outbreak in IRAN (medrxiv)
Effect: The available data is too small to identify seasonal patterns and make predictable variation in value

Study: Social distancing strategies for curbing the COVID-19 epidemic (medrxiv)
Effect: summer months will have lower peaks than winter outbreaks

Study: Preliminary evidence that higher temperatures are associated with lower incidence of COVID-19, for cases reported globally up to 29th February 2020 (medrxiv)
Effect: Higher average temperature was strongly associated with lower COVID-19 incidence for temperatures of 1Â°C and higher

Study: Spread of SARS-CoV-2 Coronavirus likely to be constrained by climate (medrxiv)
Factors Described: Temperature, Precipitation Sum, Surface Shortwave Radiation, Actual Evapotranspiration
Effect: Mean temperature and evapotranspiration (a surrogate of humidity) are the predictors best explaining the distribution of outbreaks of the virus, with areas either too cold or too hot, or too wet, having lower exposure to outbreaks

Study: Projecting the transmission dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 through the post-pandemic period (medrxiv)
Effect: Determinant on if immunity to SARS-COV-2 is permanent

Study: Application of the ARIMA model on the COVID-2019 epidemic dataset (Data Brief)
Effect: Prevalence and Incidence of COVID19 is not influenced by seasonality

Study: Potential impact of seasonal forcing on a SARS-CoV-2 pandemic (medrxiv)
Effect: Seasonal variation might slow down the virus but seasonality alone is unlikely to end the SARS-COV-2 spread

Study: A spatial model of CoVID-19 transmission in England and Wales: early spread and peak timing (medrxiv)
